The contents of this document are subject to revision without notice due to continued progress in methodology, design and manufacturing. Simonsoft shall have no liability for any error or damage of any kind resulting from the use of this document.

section.title: Preface
section.p: Welcome to the Simonsoft Techdoc v2.0 Document Type Definition (DTD) User Guide. This document describes the use of the Techdoc DTD structure, elements and the attributes. The Techdoc DTD is fully XML compliant (see ).

Techdoc documents can be created using any XML-compatible editors. However, Arbortext Editor provides a complete environment to handle complex documents including XML features required for modularizing, profiling, link handling, and so forth.

itemlist.title: Prerequisites
itemlist.p: Prerequisites for successful use of this manual include knowledge of the following concepts:

li.p: The XML tools used in conjunction with the DTDs

section.title: Overview
section.p: The Techdoc v2.0 User Guide contains all the essential information about every facet of the Techdoc DTD. This section provides an overview of this document.
The Techdoc User Guide is divided into the following chapters:

entry.p: This chapter is named as Preface. It is divided into sections, explaining the prerequisites required to use this manual effectively, the text conventions used and overview section of the User Guide.
The Techdoc DTD Overview chapter (see ) gives an overview of the Techdoc DTD along with the required background information.

The main part of this User Guide is collection of chapters describing every major aspect of the Techdoc DTD. They are designed to cover everything, from various types of item lists to in-line elements, a discussion on meta-data, to equations, and so on.
The following topics are covered in the descriptive chapters:
The DTD Element Reference chapter (see ) is an alphabetically-ordered reference that contains a detailed description for every element in Techdoc DTD, including all attributes.

section.title: Text Conventions
section.p: The Techdoc User Guide uses a number of text conventions. This section lists the conventions used in the User Guide, along with some suggested examples.

section.title: Element, Attribute and Entity Names
section.p: The DTD element, attribute and entity names in text are identified with a mono spaced font, as shown in the following example: The ixterm element is used for identifying index terms in text.

section.title: Attribute Values
section.p: The Attribute values are identified as quoted text in the manual, as shown in the following example: The type attribute has a value number that sets the numlist type to numbered.

section.title: Techdoc DTD Overview
section.p: The Techdoc DTD is developed as a general purpose DTD for creating all kinds of technical documents.
This chapter gives an overview of the Techdoc DTD.

section.title: Techdoc Document Structural Overview
section.p: This section provides a detailed structural overview of Techdoc document.
displays the structure of a Techdoc document.
A Techdoc document consists of a Meta-data section, a Front matter, a document Body, and a Back matter.

section.title: Techdoc Document Meta-data
section.p: The meta-data section in a Techdoc document is described below:
The Techdoc meta-data identifies a document rather than a product and it includes a doc-id element that contains the document number, revision, language, and date.
displays the structure of a meta-data section in Techdoc document.
The meta-data section in Techdoc document contains elements that define information about the document.

The meta-data section comprises the confidentiality classification and general information of the document. The document number, language, revision and date can be listed. The document name, title, subtitle, English title and user information, if any, can be recorded. The meta-data section also lists information about the authors and editors of the document, with the document variants and revision history.
discusses the detail information of meta-data in Techdoc.

section.title: Techdoc Document Front Matter
section.p: The Front Matter in the Techdoc document contains the information about the document, its title page, infosection, and table of content.
displays the structure of Front Matter in the Techdoc document.

numlist.p: The Front Matter in a Techdoc document is divided into following sections:

li.p: The first Distribution List Information or Title Page section are optional and are displayed based on the type of the documents used. Distribution List Information is typically used for informal documents and internal memos whereas a Title Page is used for formal documents.
Enclosure list is optional and is used for Techdoc document collections.
Abstract gives the reader an overview of the document (optional). Zero or more titled blocks are allowed and are used for various purposes such as summaries, meeting participant lists and so on.

section.title: Techdoc Document Body
section.p: The Body section in a Techdoc document contains all the relevant information in a document. The other information in a Techdoc document is considered as supplementary.
displays the structure of Body section in a Techdoc document.
The chapter-level structure is used to create documents that require a chapter structure. The body of Techdoc documents can contain up to five chapter levels, nested within each other.
discusses the chapter-level structures in more detail.

section.title: Techdoc Document Back Matter
section.p: The Back matter in a Techdoc document can contain supplementary chapters and index. This section is optional but contains usually valuable information to the reader and it is therefore recommended to include.

section.title: Metadata

note.p: The meta-data section is pending further development of Simonsoft Subversion adapter. This section will be updated when the adapter is released. To ensure smooth migration to a release with an updated meta-data content model, use this section as little as possible.

section.p: This chapter provides an overview of the meta-data section in Techdoc documents. Meta-data is information about information and includes details such as the document title, the document number, the date, and so on.
describes the meta-data elements in detail. describes the top-level meta-data element.
Techdoc documents have a single meta-data structure that contains information about the document.

section.title: Meta-Data Element Overview
section.p: Document meta-data contains information pertaining to a document. The meta-data information is stored in the meta-data element.
Arbortext Editor supports the user with a specially designed dialog box for entering all meta-data for a document.
contains the detailed descriptions of all meta-data elements.

section.title: Techdata
section.p: The techdata content model is pending a future release.

section.title: Front Matter
section.p: The Front matter of a Techdoc document contains a title page, one or more optional infosections and one or more optional table of contents.

section.title: Document Front
section.p: Techdoc documents with the document element as the root element, have an optional frontm element. The frontm element contains the front matter of the document.

numlist.p: The frontm element has the following subelements:

li.p: The tag have an optional graphic element for inserting illustrations on the front page. See .

Some documents have need for more information than just a title on the front page (abstract, copyright, and so on) so we introduce the infosection element that contains a lot of elements. You can have an infosection in another infosection. It is optional. See .

The toc element is also optional and will generate the usual table of contents. But it can also be used for list of figures, list of tables and so on. You can use several toc elements for your document. See .

section.title: Chapters and Sections
section.p: A Techdoc document can contain information of nested sections. All documentation requires a structure and to use chapters and sections. In the section levels, a sub-section structure can be used.

section.title: Chapter Structure
section.p: Techdoc documents can contain up to five chapter levels, ranging from section element (first chapter level) to section element (fifth chapter level). The chapter levels in Techdoc documents are nested within each other. Tag-wise you can nest more than five levels, but style-wise we do not support it.

section.title: Chapter Contents Overview
section.p: The structure of first chapter level in a Techdoc document is displayed in .
A Techdoc chapter contains a title.
A section contains number of block-level elements ranging from ordinary paragraphs, lists and notes. This section offers a quick overview of the elements.

li.p: The p element identifies ordinary paragraphs and are generally used in the block-level structures. This element is used to identify the text. This element contains number of in-line elements and allows inserting in-line equations, cross-references to other parts of the document, etc. See for more information on ordinary paragraph and its in-line elements

Notes and admonitions call the reader’s attention. Notes inform the readers about the subject and Admonitions warn the reader about the possible risks in connection to the subject. Notes and admonitions are discussed in
The following are the some of the Block level elements:
The figure element - to create and generate illustrations.
The table element - to insert tables.
The example element - to display the file examples.
Up to five chapter levels can be nested within a chapter. For Instance: section, section, section and section can be inserted in section element. The same rule follows at all the chapter levels.

section.title: Lists
section.p: The following sections describe the different list types and the structure of lists in the Techdoc DTD.

section.title: List Types
section.p: Lists are an important structure in DTD and fall into two broad categories: simple listing of items and step-by-step procedure lists.

itemlist.p: The following are the main list types in the Techdoc DTD:

section.title: Unordered (bullet) Lists
section.p: Unordered lists are used for listing items in a document that have no specific order. These lists are created using the itemlist element. For a detailed discussion on the anatomy of itemlist, See .

section.title: Alpha–numeric Lists
section.p: Alpha–numeric lists are used for creating ordered numeric or alphabetical lists. These lists are created using the numlist element. For more details on the anatomy of a alpha-numeric list, see .
The following list types are available in a numlist:

entry.p: A number list is a list where either the order of the list items is important or there is a need to make cross-references to individual list items. An ordered list is formatted using consecutive numbers beginning with 1.

An alpha_lower list is a list where either the order of the list items is important or there is a need to make cross-references to individual list items. An alphabetic itemlist is formatted using consecutive letters beginning with a and the suffix lower indicates that it will be formatted with non-capital letters.

An alpha_upper list is a list where either the order of the list items is important or there is a need to make cross-references to individual list items. An alphabetic itemlist is formatted using consecutive letters beginning with a and the suffix upper indicates that it will be formatted with capital letters.

A roman_lower list is a list where either the order of the list items is important or there is a need to make cross-references to individual list items. An ordered list is formatted using consecutive non-capital roman numbers beginning with i.

A roman_upper list is a list where either the order of the list items is important or there is a need to make cross-references to individual list items. An ordered list is formatted using consecutive capital roman numbers beginning with I.

note.p: Alpha—numerical lists must not be used for writing step-by-step procedures, instead the procedure structure should be used.

section.title: Definition Lists
section.p: Definition lists are used for listing terms and their definitions in unordered two-column lists. The definition list structure is useful for presenting command parameters and their definitions can be listed conveniently using a definition list.
Definition lists are created using the deflist element that functions as a container for the definition list itself. For more details on the anatomy of a definition list, See .

section.title: Step-by-step Procedure
section.p: Step–by–step procedures is in a way a list but we want to handle it with another kind of content model. Therefore we have created the procedure element, that functions as a container for the step-by-step list. For more details on the anatomy of a procedure, see .

note.p: Alpha–numerical lists must not be used for writing step-by-step procedures, instead the procedure structure should be used.

section.title: The Anatomy of a List
section.p: This section describes the anatomy of the lists in a Techdoc document.

section.title: Common List Components
section.p: The following are the list of components used in Techdoc that are common for all types of lists, as is shown in .

li.p: A list can have an optional introductory paragraph and should always end with a colon (:). It is important to note that the introductory paragraph should be nested within the proper list-tag so that if the list is moved elsewhere in the document, the introduction is moved along with it.

An ordinary list consists of two or more list items. A list item in turn contains one or more phrases or sentences, optionally interspersed with notes, admonitions or tables. Notes and admonitions must be related to the list item in which they are placed.

note.p: In some cases there can be appropriate to use an one-item list, therefore we allow it. But, think twice before using that kind of construction.

li.p: A definition list differs slightly from other lists. Due to the nature of the two-column list, only the definition part of e definition list item allows for more than one p element. This is a logical consequence of the construction of a definition list; a term should be seen as a definition list item's title.

note.p: A note or admonition should never appear without an adjoining paragraph in the list item; a note or an admonition connects to the subject described in the paragraph, but can never replace it.

li.p: The term of a definition list item can be replaced by a graphic image. This is a useful feature, for example, when describing icons in a graphical user interface or parts of a product.

section.title: Sub-lists
section.p: Most of the Techdoc list items allow sub-lists, but some differences exist between the different list items. The differences are as follows:

li.p: Alpha-numeric lists allow recursive alpha-numeric lists for a total of three levels. It can also have definition lists or an unordered list placed in a list item.

section.title: Graphics
section.p: This chapter discusses the illustrations used in Techdoc documents.
The following three types of illustrations are supported:

entry.p: Figures are large, block-level illustrations with a title. Figures are created using the figure element. The figure element is a wrapper for other elements. See .
In-line graphic are small illustrations inserted into paragraph text. In-line graphic are created using the graphic element. See .
Procedure figures is a way to do larger graphics in a step-by-step instruction. We use the procfig element for this. See .

itemlist.p: Illustrations are always stored in external files that are linked to the document. This method of handling graphic has the following advantages:

li.p: Illustrations can be updated by modifying or replacing the original picture. There is no need to re-import the illustration into the document.
The same illustration can be used in many different documents.
An illustration can be reused in the same document.
Illustrations can be processed separately from document content. This makes file format conversions easy. It also makes easy for the authors to update illustrations while updating a document.

itemlist.p: The following graphic file formats are supported in Techdoc documents:

section.title: In-line Graphics
section.p: An in-line graphic is an image that is located inside a paragraph. In-line graphic are created using the graphic element.
Refer the manual of the authoring system for more information on the creation of in-line graphic.

section.title: Figures
section.p: A figure is a block-level illustration. Figures are created using the figure element.

itemlist.p: The figure element serves as a wrapper for the following elements:

li.p: The graphic element holds the file reference to the illustration.
The title element holds a title for the illustration.
The figuretext element shall contain a descriptive text for the illustration.
The introtext element shall contain an introductory text for the illustration.

The optional element figuretable can be used in certain cases. For example when you want to show a display with different menus. The reader of your document thinks it is a graphic but for translation purposes you want to keep it as a table.

section.title: Tables
section.p: A table is useful for showing large number of specific, related facts or statistics in a framework. It is also useful for data comparisons because the arrangement of information is in columns and rows according to the CALS table standard.
Every table has a title that indicates the purpose and subject of the table.

A table can use any number of header rows to indicate the subject and division of columns. Footer rows are also allowed and offers supplementary information to the reader. Table notes (See ) are always placed under the table footer. Both headers and footers are allowed to span one or more header or footer cells, respectively; the number is usually determined by the writer.
A table can have any number of columns and rows. Individual cells can span one or several other cells.

section.title: Table Caption
section.p: Every table is assigned an identifying title. The table title is placed immediately above the table.

section.title: Table Headers and Footers
section.p: Tables often use header and footer rows, created using thead and tfoot elements, respectively. Both header and footer functions like any other table row so that any number of rows can be allowed and the span of each header and footer cell is determined by the writer. Within each header or footer cell, the writer can either create any number of table paragraphs or table lists, just as the same while creating ordinary table cells.

section.title: Table Cells
section.p: A table consists of a number of table cells arranged in rows and columns, in addition to headers and footers. A table cell can span one or more table cells and can contain either paragraphs (the p element) or lists (the itemlist, numlist, deflist element) or all.
A table paragraph can contain most of the in-line elements as used in any other ordinary paragraph.

note.p: A table should not be used for describing computer interaction. See for more information on computer interaction description.

section.p: A table cell can also use table notes. Table notes are used for inserting comments and references about the information in tables and table cells in table footers. See .

section.title: Table Notes
section.p: A table cell can contain tablefn that are either pointers to the additional information about the subject or information related to the entire table. Notes are always placed underneath the table footer.

section.title: Notes and Admonitions
section.p: Techdoc document contains two methods (Notes and Admonitions) that draw the reader's attention from the text flow to the subject. The method used depends on the importance and subject matter of the item.

section.title: Notes
section.p: The note element calls the reader’s attention to a particular piece of information related to, but not directly connected to the subject. For example, a note can be used to draw attention to important information for the reader or special aspects of the subject that the reader would not anticipate.

It is important that a note should be placed where it is required and not after the unrelated information. For example, it is rarely a good idea to place notes last in a section, where the note probably comes too late to be of any use.

A note should ideally contain one or two sentences and very rarely more than one paragraph, even though the DTD allows a note to consist of multiple paragraphs and lists. Longer notes divert the reader's attention from the main subject for too long and it is therefore possible that the reader to miss some vital information present in the text flow. If a note requires several paragraphs or a list, the subject of the note should probably be explored in the main text flow instead, perhaps in its own section. That is certainly the case if the note requires a step-by-step procedure.

section.title: Admonitions
section.p: Admonitions are used to avoid risk of data loss, equipment damage or personal injury in connection to the information presented in the text flow.

It is very important that the right type of admonition is used. The reader must be able to easily spot the admonition immediately preceding the task and the information must be clear, concise and unambiguous. The consequences of a poorly-presented admonition can be serious; a reader that fails to observe a danger notice, can be exposed to a potentially lethal situation.

The writers should be aware of the legal aspects that complicate the use of the admonitions. Using the wrong type of admonition may result in being liable for the damage caused when information in a manual is taken too lightly and the wrong action is taken by the customer.

The following five types of admonitions are used, defined by attribute values in the admonition element and sorted with a numbered prefix on severity level (1 for the most severe, 5 for the least severe):

entry.p: A danger notice is used when there is a risk of personal injury. The danger notice must precede the step or action that involves a risk.
A warning notice is used when there is a risk of damage to data or to a program, a device or a system. The warning notice must precede the step or action that involves a risk.
A caution notice is used when there is a risk of system failure or service interruption. The caution notice must precede the step or action that involves a risk.
A important notice is used when there are certain tools that must be used to not damage the product.
A environment notice is used when there is risk of environmental damage. The enviroment notice must precede the step or action that involves a risk.

section.title: Cross-references
section.p: This chapter describes how the cross-reference and hypertext link system works in Techdoc documents. It also describes how to set or write links and cross-references that are correctly formatted, regardless on how links are reformatted for different publishing media.

Most authoring systems shield authors from the technical details on how to create cross-references and links to some extent. However, it is very important to know how to write cross-references and hypertext links, because authors must adhere to the same conventions otherwise costly mishaps may occur.

Cross-references are used to point from one location in a document to another, for example: from a point in a sentence to an illustration below the paragraph or to a section that deals more closely with the subject. Cross-references can obviously refer locations in other documents, for example: chapters, sections or illustrations and other libraries as well. Hypertext links are used for the same end in online documents; a word or a phrase becomes an active hot spot which, when clicked or when activated by some other means, traverses the link, activates it and navigates to the target.

itemlist.p: In Techdoc documents, the following methods are provided for making cross-references and hypertext links:

li.p: A simple cross-reference system for making cross-references and hypertext links where both the link source and link target are located in the same file. This system is supported by all authoring and publishing systems.

section.p: Arbortext Editor provides automated support for creating cross-references and hypertext links. It is possible to create the links manually, but care must be taken to ensure that the links really do work as intended.

section.title: Cross-reference Source Elements
section.p: A cross-reference and hypertext link source element contains a reference to a link target that identifies the information of interest.

itemlist.p: The following elements can be used to create cross-references and hypertext links:

li.p: The xref element is used to create cross-references where link source and link target are located in the same file. The element serves as a marker that is replaced by generated text in formatted documents. Cross-references are formatted differently in paper and online documentation. In online documents, cross-references are usually turned into hypertext links.

section.title: Cross-reference Link Targets
section.p: In theory, it is possible to make a cross-reference or hypertext link to any element that has an xml:id attribute. In practice, only selected elements are suitable as cross-reference and hypertext link targets.

itemlist.p: The following elements are recommended cross-reference and hypertext link targets:

section.title: Writing Cross-references
section.p: Writing correct cross-references can be difficult, because they are written in such a way that the reference works regardless on how the cross-reference locator (the xref element) is formatted.

section.title: Cross-references in a Single File
section.p: Provided that both the cross-reference source and the cross-reference target are located in the same file, it is possible to create simple cross-reference links using the linkend attribute of the xref cross-reference locator. The linkend attribute must be set to the same value as that of the xml:id attribute of the cross-reference target element.

numlist.p: The following procedure shows how to create a simple cross-reference:

li.p: Assign a unique identifier to the xml:id attribute of the link target.
See for a list of legal cross-reference target elements.
Insert an xref element at the location where the cross-reference is desired.

section.title: Simple Cross-reference
section.p: In a formatted document, the xref element is replaced by automatically-generated text. The generated text usually begins with a keyword indicating the type of cross-reference target. The keyword is followed by the generated text, identifying the cross-reference target. The text can vary depending on the cross-reference formatting rules in force. The presence of the keyword makes it possible to construct cross-reference sentences that are grammatically correct, even when the rest of the generated text varies.

section.title: Web links
section.p: Links to web URLs can be created using link element. This is an in-line element used to create links to web URLs. Links can be inserted by selecting or without selecting the text in the same way as that of internal links.

li.p: When web link is created without selecting text, then the web URI specified is visible as generated text.
When web link is created by selecting the text, then the selected text gets marked as hyperlink.

section.title: Text and In-line Elements
section.p: This chapter discusses about the in-line elements and how to use them in the Techdoc DTD.

section.title: Overview
section.p: In-line elements in the Techdoc DTD identify semantic information in the text flow. Every semantically important piece of information in text must be marked up for later identification and processing.

An important use of in-line elements is marking up words for easier visual identification of semantically important parts of the text flow. For example, the information identified with the sups element is formatted so that the characters within the element are printed slightly above the height of the surrounding characters.

All in-line elements, with the exception of the tablefn (table-note) element, are available from within an ordinary paragraph (a p element), but many also appear in other information types where the full range of in-line elements is not desired, for example in the term of a definition list.

note.p: The tablefn in-line element only appears in a table cell paragraph.

section.p: provides an overview of the in-line elements. For more detailed information about each and every in-line element, See .

section.title: In-line Elements in Techdoc DTD
section.p: This section describes the in-line elements used in the Techdoc DTD. For more detailed descriptions, See .

section.title: emph
section.p: The emph element is used for emphasizing words and phrases in the text flow. This element should not be used for semantic markup, that is, to identify a special type of information in the text flow. Set text to bold, italics, underscore, and so on.

section.title: graphic
section.p: The graphic element is used to insert in-line graphic images. See .

section.title: link
section.p: The link element identifies words and phrases used as hypertext links, where the link source and link target are located in the same file. See .

section.title: label
section.p: The label element identifies for instance non-translatable words and phrases, including code, in the text flow. It can also be used to identify code fragments that are translatable, since some high-level script languages are language-dependent.

section.title: br
section.p: The br element is used to insert a forced line break. The content after this element starts in the next line with same indentation as previous line. For more information on br element, See .

section.title: quote
section.p: The quote element identifies quoted text in the text flow. For more information on quote element, See .

note.p: The style sheet normally adds quotation marks before and after the quoted text. The writer should never include quotation marks when quoting text, unless the quotation marks are part of the quoted text.

section.title: sub
section.p: The sub element is used to identify the text to be treated as subscript. For more information on the sub element, See .

section.title: sup
section.p: The sup element is used to identify the text to be treated as superscript. For more information on the sup element, See .

section.title: symbol
section.p: The symbol element shall be used for symbols that can be hard to choose correct one in the symbol library. For instance inches and feet. For more information on symbol element, See .

section.title: term
section.p: The term element can for instance be used to identify terms that can be reused within the document. For more information on term element, See .

section.title: xref
section.p: The xref element is used for making cross-references to the blocks of information in other sections of the document. For more information on cross-references and links in Techdoc documents, See .

section.title: Computer Interaction
section.p: Computer interaction is a term used in this manual, to discuss how to identify and describe man-machine interaction, graphical user interfaces (GUIs) and keyboard shortcuts.
See for more information.

section.title: Back Matter
section.p: This chapter describes how to use the back matter components. Back matter is optional but usually contain valuable information to the reader. It usually contains glossary, different appendix, and so on. The main reason to put it in a back matter is to be able to set the page counters for style in a different way and such things.
The back matter contains mostly the same elements as in a section but also the index element.
displays the structure of a Techdoc document backm matter.

figure.title: Back Matter of a Techdoc Document

section.title: Index section
section.p: An index is a systematic arrangement of entries designed to enable users to locate information in a document. The ixterm element is used to generate index with index entries in the document.
Additionally the index element must be inserted in the Backm section for enabling the index table generation (support depends on style sheet used).

section.title: Techdoc DTD Element Reference
section.p: This chapter is an element reference for the Techdoc DTD.

section.title: admon
section.p: The element is declared as follows:

section.title: Context
section.p: entry, section, backm, infosection, introtext, itemlist, numlist, procedure, proctext, li

section.title: Description
section.p: The admon element is used to give cautionary instructions to be followed to avoid the risks or danger in connection with the subject. An admonition must always be used when there is a risk of data loss, equipment damage or personal injury.
The default admonition symbols that represent the different types of admonitions can be replaced with other symbols by using the graphic element, first in the admon element's style definition.

note.p: Refer the local style rules before changing the admon symbol.

admon.p: Using an admonition of the type warning when the type danger is called for may cause the user to take the admonition too lightly. This may result in personal injury or equipment damage.

section.p: The admon element has the following attributes:

entry.p: The type attribute identifies the type of admonition used. There are five possible values: 1–danger, 2–warning, 3–caution, 4–important and , 5–environment. Default value iscaution.

li.p: The value 1–danger should be used when there is a risk of damage to data or to a program, device or system.
The value 2–warning should be used when there is a risk of damage to data or to a program, device or system.
The value 3–caution should be used when there is a risk of system failure or service interruption.
The value 4–important should be used when there is a risk of injury to a person.
The value 5–environment should be used when there is a risk of injury to a person.

section.title: as-is
section.p: The element is declared as follows:

section.title: Context
section.p: example, entry, section, backm, infosection, introtext, itemlist, numlist, procedure, proctext, li

section.title: Description
section.p: The as-is element element is used as an example text that is to be presented as-is. White space and line breaks are preserved. The text is formatted as mono spaced, so any use beyond coding examples is limited.
The as-is element has the following attributes:

section.title: backm
section.p: The element is declared as follows:

section.title: Description
section.p: The backm element comprises the backmatter section in a Techdoc document and has optional sections (appendixes), optional table of contents and an optional index table.
The backm element has the following attributes:

section.title: body
section.p: The element is declared as follows:

section.title: Description
section.p: The body element comprises the body of a document. The body element can contains one or more section elements.
The body element has the following attributes:

section.title: br
section.p: The element is declared as follows:

section.title: Context
section.p: The br element is included in the DTD but not used in the default content model.

section.title: Description
section.p: The br element provides flexibility for the user to wrap or enter the text in new line wherever needed. The content after this element is discontinued and is started in the next line with same indentation as previous line.
The br element has no attributes:

section.title: datagroup
section.p: The element is declared as follows:

section.title: Description
section.p: The datagroup element is for future use, not modeled yet.
The datagroup element has no attributes.:

section.title: defdesc
section.p: The element is declared as follows:

section.title: Description
section.p: The defitem element encloses the definition item. It may contain one or more definition paragraphs.
The defitem element has the following attributes:

section.title: defitem
section.p: The element is declared as follows:

section.title: Description
section.p: The defitem element encloses the definition item. It may contain one or more definition paragraphs.
The defitem element has the following attributes:

section.title: deflist
section.p: The element is declared as follows:

section.title: Context
section.p: entry, section, backm, infosection, introtext, figuretext, proctext, prereqs, li, note, admon, frame

section.title: Description
section.p: The deflist element encloses the definition items (consisting of a defterm followed by a definition).
The deflist element can contain an optional introductory title (a title element), followed by one or more definition items.
The deflist element has the following attributes:

section.title: defterm
section.p: The element is declared as follows:

section.title: Description
section.p: The defterm element encloses the definition term.
The defterm element has the following attributes:

section.title: description
section.p: The element is declared as follows:

section.title: Description
section.p: The description element encloses the descriptionblock. This element contains an optional title followed by one or more descriptionblock. The description element is to be used in situations requiring addition layout control. It will create a two-column layout as default with text in the left column and graphics in the right column.

For descriptive information, use this element rather then just paragraphs, tables, and figures. Group the information together by using descriptionblock. To be able to reuse and profile the information in a good way, the use of description is preferable.
The description element has the following attributes:

section.title: descriptionblock
section.p: The element is declared as follows:

section.title: Description
section.p: The descriptionblock element contains one or more optional figure elements and one or more optional descriptiontext elements.
The descriptionblock element has the following attributes:

section.title: descriptiontext
section.p: The element is declared as follows:

section.title: Description
section.p: The descriptiontext element contains the descriptive text of a descriptionblock. The element contains on or more itemlist, numlist, deflist, p, admon and note elements.
The descriptiontext element has the following attributes:

section.title: document
section.p: The element is declared as follows:

section.title: Context
section.p: The document is the root element in the Techdoc DTD

section.title: Description
section.p: The document element is the root element in the Techdoc DTD.
The document element has the following attributes:

entry.p: The type attribute specifies if the document type, the default selection is:
The docno attribute specifies document number.
The creationdate attribute specifies when the document was created.
The createdby attribute specifies the creator of the document.

section.title: dotfill
section.p: The element is declared as follows:

section.title: Context
section.p: The dotfill element is included in the DTD but not used in the default content model.

section.title: Description
section.p: The dotfill element can be used to insert leading or trailing dots.
The dotfill element has no attributes.

section.title: endnote
section.p: The element is declared as follows:

section.title: Context
section.p: entry, li

section.title: Description
section.p: The in-line element endnote is used to create an endnote. Reference mark is inserted at current position and the endnote referencemark and content is added at the end of the element.
The endnote element has the following attributes:

section.title: emph
section.p: The element is declared as follows:

section.title: Context
section.p: p, ixterm, emph., qoute, sup, sub, label, term, link.

section.title: Description
section.p: The emph element is an in-line element that helps identifying the important information in the text flow. Default value for the element is bold=yes.
The emph element has the following attributes:

entry.p: The bold attribute specifies if the element should be formatted asbold.
The italic attribute specifies if the element should be formatted asitalic.
The underscr attribute specifies if the element should be formatted asunderscr.
The strikethr attribute specifies if the element should be formatted asstrikethr.
The case attribute specifies if the element should be formatted as upper case or lower case.
The color attribute specifies the color of the element.
The shading attribute specifies the shading of the element.

section.title: example
section.p: The element is declared as follows:

section.title: Context
section.p: section, backm, infosection, introtext, figuretext, proctext, prereqs, descriptiontext, note, frame

section.title: Description
section.p: The example element encloses the as-is element. The element also contains an optional title.
The example element has the following attributes:

section.title: figure
section.p: The element is declared as follows:

section.title: Context
section.p: admon, section, backm, infosection, li

section.title: Description
section.p: The figure element encloses the block-level graphics or table in a Techdoc documents. This element also contains a figure title, optional introductory text and an optional figure text.
The figure element has the following attributes:

section.title: figuretable
section.p: The element is declared as follows:

section.title: Description
section.p: The element figuretable can be used in certain cases. For example when you want to show a display with different menus. The reader of your document thinks it is a graphic but for translation purposes you want to keep it as a table.

section.title: figuretext
section.p: The element is declared as follows:

section.title: Context
section.p: frontm, figure, procfig

section.title: Description
section.p: The figuretext element identifies source information about a figure or procfig.
The figuretext element has the following attributes:

section.title: fnref
section.p: The element is declared as follows:

section.title: Context
section.p: p, ixterm, emph, quote, sup, sub, label, term, link

section.title: Description
section.p: The fnref element is a cross-reference to a footnote or a endnote element.
The fnref element has the following attributes:

entry.p: The linkend attribute holds the ID reference to the linked element.

section.title: footnote
section.p: The element is declared as follows:

section.title: Context
section.p: p, ixterm, emph, quote, sup, sub, label, term, link

section.title: Description
section.p: The in-line element footnote is used to create a footnote. Reference mark is inserted at current position and the footnote itself is added at the end of current page.
The footnote element has the following attributes:

section.title: frame
section.p: The element is declared as follows:

section.title: Context
section.p: The frame element is included in the DTD but not used in the default content model.

section.title: Description
section.p: The frame element can be used to created enclosing frames.
The frame element has no attributes defined.

section.title: frontm
section.p: The element is declared as follows:

section.title: Description
section.p: The frontm element contains the frontm matter of the document. The frontm matter optionally includes graphic, followed by one or more optional infosections and one or more toc elements.
The frontm element has the following attributes:

section.title: graphic
section.p: The element is declared as follows:

section.title: Context
section.p: table, entry, section, frontm, backm, infosection, figure, procfig, li, p, note, admon, ixterm, emph, quote, sub, sup, label, term, link

section.title: Description
section.p: The graphic element is a placeholder for graphic image file references. The element is treated as an in-line element when having the element p as an ancestor. The element is treated as a block in all other contexts.
The graphic element has the following attributes:

entry.p: The fileref attribute is container for path of the graphic. This path can be either an absolute or relative path.

The value of the contentwidth attribute is the size to which the graphic width should be scaled if scalefit = yes. For example, if the value of contentwidth is 4.5in creates an image 4.5 inches wide. The height is scaled with the same factor; if the actual size of the image is 3x2 inches, the image size in the document is 4.5x3 inches.
Valid units are: pt, pc, in, mm, and cm.

The value of the contentheight attribute is the size to which the graphic width should be scaled if scalefit = yes. For example, if the value of contentheight is 3in creates an image 3 inches wide. The height is scaled with the same factor; if the actual size of the image is 2x3 inches, the image size in the document is 3x4.5 inches.
Valid units are: pt, pc, in, mm, and cm.
The halign attribute sets the horizontal alignment of the graphic.
The scale attribute sets the scaling factor of the picture height and width, given as a percentage. The default value is 100

The scalefit attribute controls the scaling of the graphic and rescales the picture automatically according to either contentwidth or contentheight, if neither of them are defined the scalefit attribute scales the graphic to fit the current viewport (column, cell etc). Default value of this attribute is no
The optionalview attribute controls the displayed view of intelligent graphics.

section.title: index
section.p: The element is declared as follows:

section.title: Description
section.p: This stand-alone element allows to create an index table. This element is inserted only once into the document and is left empty. It contains an optional title element. The index element must be inserted within the backm section.
The index element has the following attributes:

entry.p: The type attribute are available for future customizations.

section.title: infosection
section.p: The element is declared as follows:

section.title: Description
section.p: The infosection element holds any additional information needed in the frontm of the document. Examples could be:
The infosection element has the following attributes:

entry.p: The type attribute indicates type of infosection.
The indicator attribute is used for user defined numbering.

section.title: introtext
section.p: The element is declared as follows:

section.title: Context
section.p: frontm, figure, procfig

section.title: Description
section.p: The introtext element to insert any introductory information about a figure or procfig.
The introtext element has the following attributes:

section.title: itemid
section.p: The element is declared as follows:

section.title: Context
section.p: The itemid element is included in the DTD but not used in the default content model.

section.title: Description
section.p: The itemid element encloses an identifier for future use.
The itemid element has the following attributes:

section.title: itemlist
section.p: The element is declared as follows:

section.title: Context
section.p: entry, section, backm, infosection, introtext, figuretext, proctext, prereqs, li, note, admon, frame

section.title: Description
section.p: The itemlist element encloses the unordered listitems. This element contains an optional title, optional introductory admonitions or paragraphs followed by one or more listitems.
The itemlist element has the following attributes:

section.title: ixterm
section.p: The element is declared as follows:

section.title: Context
section.p: p, ixterm, emph, quote, sup, sub, label, term, link.

section.title: Description
section.p: Each ixterm element generates an entry in the final index table.
The ixterm element has the following attributes:

section.title: label
section.p: The element is declared as follows:

section.title: Context
section.p: p, ixterm, emph, quote, sup, sub, label, term, link.

section.title: Description
section.p: The label element is used for text, that are to be presented as it is.
The label element has the following attributes:

entry.p: The type attribute specifies what kind of text the label contains. Default selection:

section.title: li
section.p: The element is declared as follows:

section.title: Context
section.p: itemlist, numlist.

section.title: Description
section.p: The li element encloses each item in an itemlist or numlist. This element can contain one or more ordinary paragraphs, notes, admonitions, figures or tables, alternatively another itemlist or numlist element.
The li element has the following attributes:

section.title: link
section.p: The element is declared as follows:

section.title: Context
section.p: p, ixterm, emph, quote, sup, sub, label, term, link.

section.title: Description
section.p: The link element is an in-line element that identifies a word or a phrase, that is used as a link in the document itself or an online document.
The link element has the following attributes:

entry.p: The uri attribute specifies the address to the external document.
The linkend attribute specifies the ID within the document.
The type attribute is available for future customizations.

section.title: note
section.p: The element is declared as follows:

section.title: Context
section.p: entry, section, backm, infosection, introtext, itemlist, numlist, procedure, proctext, li.

section.title: Description
section.p: The note element is used to insert notes in between the text flow. The notes contain the information that are closely related to the subject in the text flow.
The note element has the following attributes:

entry.p: The type attribute specifies what kind of note it is.

section.title: numlist
section.p: The element is declared as follows:

section.title: Context
section.p: entry, section, backm, infosection, introtext, figuretext, proctext, prereqs, li, note, admon, frame

section.title: Description
section.p: The numlist element encloses the ordered listitems. This element contains an optional title, optional introductory admonitions or paragraphs followed by one or more listitems.
The numlist type, number, alpha_upper, alpha_lower, roman_upper or roman_lower, is chosen with an attribute, type.
The itemlist element has the following attributes:

entry.p: The restart attribute specifies if the numbering should be restarted or not.
The type attribute specifies type of numbering scheme. Default selection:

section.title: p
section.p: The element is declared as follows:

section.title: Context
section.p: entry, section, backm, infosection, introtext, figuretext, proctext, prereqs, li, note, admon, frame

section.title: Description
section.p: The p element is a block-level element used to insert ordinary paragraphs. This element contains number of in-line elements ranging from elements used for emphasis to an element for in-line graphics (graphic.
The p element has the following attributes:

section.title: procedure
section.p: The element is declared as follows:

section.title: Context
section.p: infosection, section, backm

section.title: Description
section.p: The procedure element encloses the procstep element. This element contains an optional title, optional introductory admonitions or paragraphs followed by one or more procstep. The procedure element creates a two-column layout meant for a step-by-step instruction with text in the left column and graphics and figure-text in the right column. Each procstep element will generate a new number in the procedure.
The procedure element has the following attributes:

entry.p: The restart attribute specifies if the numbering should be restarted or not.

section.title: procfig
section.p: The element is declared as follows:

section.title: Description
section.p: The procfig element encloses the block-level graphics or table in a procstep. This element also contains an optional figure text.
The procfig element has the following attributes:

section.title: prereqs
section.p: The element is declared as follows:

section.title: Description
section.p: The prereqs element contains any additional notes for a procedure.
The prereqs element has the following attributes:

section.title: procstep
section.p: The element is declared as follows:

section.title: Description
section.p: The procstep element contains the complete description of a procedure step. The element contains a title, one or more procfig elements, an optional proctext and optional prereqs.
The procstep element has the following attributes:

section.title: proctext
section.p: The element is declared as follows:

section.title: Description
section.p: The proctext element contains the descriptive text of a procstep. The element contains on or more itemlist, numlist, deflist, p, admon and note elements.
The proctext element has the following attributes:

section.title: quote
section.p: The element is declared as follows:

section.title: Context
section.p: p, ixterm, emph, quote, sup, sub, label, term, link.

section.title: Description
section.p: The quote element is an in-line element that identifies quoted text.
The quote element has no attributes.

section.title: section
section.p: The element is declared as follows:

section.title: Context
section.p: body, section, backm

section.title: Description
section.p: The section element comprises a section (first to fifth level). The top level sections can be considered as chapters.
The section element has the following attributes:

entry.p: The type attribute is available for customization.
The indicator attribute is used for user defined numbering.

section.title: sub
section.p: The element is declared as follows:

section.title: Context
section.p: p, ixterm, emph, quote, sup, sub, label, term, link.

section.title: Description
section.p: The sub element is an in-line element that identifies text to be treated as subscript.
The sub element has no attributes.

section.title: subtitle
section.p: The element is declared as follows:

section.title: Context
section.p: section, backm, infosection, document

section.title: Description
section.p: The subtitle element contains a subtitle of a document or section.
The subtitle element has the following attributes:

section.title: sup
section.p: The element is declared as follows:

section.title: Context
section.p: p, ixterm, emph, quote, sup, sub, label, term, link.

section.title: Description
section.p: The sup element is an in-line element that identifies text to be treated as superscript.
The sup element has no attributes.

section.title: symbol
section.p: The element is declared as follows:

section.title: Context
section.p: p, ixterm, emph, quote, sup, sub, label, term, link.

section.title: Description
section.p: The symbol element is an in-line element that identifies objects to be treated as symbols.
The symbol element has the following attributes:

entry.p: The type attribute is available for future customizations.

section.title: table
section.p: The element is declared as follows:

section.title: Context
section.p: section, backm, infosection, figure, procfig, li, admon

section.title: Description
section.p: The table element encloses the CALS table model. It contains an optional table title and one or more table groups (tgroup elements) or graphic (graphic elements).
The table element has the following attributes:

entry.p: The frame attribute controls the table borders drawn in the output. It has the possible values top, bottom, topbot, all, sides and none. The value is set by the style sheet, governed by the applicable style rules.
The colsep attribute controls whether or not to use a column separator. The colsep attribute value should normally not be changed by the author.
The rowsep attribute controls whether or not to use a row separator. The rowsep attribute value should normally not be changed by the author.

row.entry:
&defitem.custom.attrib;
The orient attribute sets the physical orientation of the table on the page. It has the possible values port (portrait) and land (landscape). This attribute may be ignored depending on the style sheet used.

entry.p: The standard CALS table attribute pgwide has been hidden and replaced by the more flexible pagesetup attribute.

section.title: techdata
section.p: The element is declared as follows:

section.title: Context
section.p: The techdata element is included in the DTD but not used in the default content model.

section.title: Description
section.p: The techdata element will contain reusable information like spare part numbers in the future .
The techdata element has the following attributes:

section.title: term
section.p: The element is declared as follows:

section.title: Context
section.p: p, ixterm, emph, quote, sup, sub, label, term, link.

section.title: Description
section.p: The term element allows to insert and define terms in a text flow.
The term element can be used to define product names or abbreviations referenced by the termref element.
The term element has the following attributes:

entry.p: The type attribute specifies type of term, product or abbrev.

section.title: termref
section.p: The element is declared as follows:

section.title: Context
section.p: p, ixterm, emph, quote, sup, sub, label, term, link.

section.title: Description
section.p: The termref element is a cross-reference to a term element.
The termref element has the following attributes:

entry.p: The linkend attribute holds the ID reference to the linked element.

section.title: tfnref
section.p: The element is declared as follows:

section.title: Context
section.p: The tfnref element is included in the DTD but not used in the default content model.

section.title: Description
section.p: The tfnref element is a cross-reference to a tablefn element.
The tfnref element has the following attributes:

entry.p: The linkend attribute holds the ID reference to the linked element.

section.title: title
section.p: The element is declared as follows:

section.title: Context
section.p: table, section, backm, infosection, figure, deflist, itemlist, numlist, procedure, procstep, index, document

section.title: Description
section.p: The title element identifies a title for elements like document, sections, infosections, figures and tables. Normally, the title element is obligatory, but it is optional in some contexts. The content of the title element is resolved when referenced by toc and/or xref.
The title element has the following attributes:

section.title: toc
section.p: The element is declared as follows:

section.title: Context
section.p: section, frontm, backm

section.title: Description
section.p: The toc element holds the table of content. The toc is typically used in the frontm or backm element, but also can be included in any section. Typical use in a section is to create list of figures or tables. The type attribute defines the type of toc and also the levels of section titles to include in the table of contents.
The toc element has the following attributes:

entry.p: The type attribute defines the type and what levels of section titles to include in the table of content.

section.title: wrapper
section.p: The element is declared as follows:

section.title: Context
section.p: body, section, backm, infosection, note, admon

section.title: Description
section.p: The wrapper element is used to add profiles to included entities.
The wrapper element has the following attributes:

section.title: xref
section.p: The element is declared as follows:

section.title: Context
section.p: p, ixterm, emph, quote, sup, sub, label, term, link.

section.title: Description
section.p: The xref element is used to create cross-references by setting the linkend attribute value to point at a specific element elsewhere in the document. The element is empty, but may cause specific formatting if the link target element is recognized by the processing software.
The xref element has the following attributes:

entry.p: The linkend attribute holds the ID reference to the linked element.

section.title: approvedby
section.p: The element is declared as follows:

section.title: Description
section.p: The approvedby element specifies the identity of document supervisor, the person with overall responsibility for issuing, storing, maintaining and discontinuing the document.
The approved-by element has no attributes.

section.title: classification
section.p: The element is declared as follows:

section.title: Description
section.p: The classification element contains specific classification data. Currently not modeled.
The classification element has no attributes.

section.title: date
section.p: The element is declared as follows:

section.title: Context
section.p: revision.

section.title: Description
section.p: The date element encloses the date. It is used to specify the date on which the latest update or change was made to the document.
The date element has no attributes.

section.title: day
section.p: The element is declared as follows:

section.title: Context
section.p: date.

section.title: Description
section.p: The day element is used to specify the day of the month in a date element. The day is represented by a two digit number in the range 01-31.
The day element has no attributes:

section.title: draftedby
section.p: The element is declared as follows:

section.title: Description
section.p: The draftedby element contains a list of the persons drafting the document. The list contains the authors of the latest draft only
The draftedby element has no attributes.

section.title: email
section.p: The element is declared as follows:

section.title: Description
section.p: The email element contains the email address for a person.
The email element has no attributes.

section.title: metadata
section.p: The element is declared as follows:

section.title: Description
section.p: The metadata element encloses the information about a document that has its own unique document identity.
Techdoc documents contain only a single meta-data section.
The label element has the following attributes:

entry.p: The Suppress attribute specifies if the metadata element should be suppressed or not.

section.title: month
section.p: The element is declared as follows:

section.title: Context
section.p: date.

section.title: Description
section.p: The month element is used to specify the month in a date element. The day is represented by a two digit number in the range 01-12.
The month element has no attributes.

section.title: name
section.p: The element is declared as follows:

section.title: Description
section.p: The name element contains the name of a person or a forum. If the name entered is the name of a person, then usually both the given and the family name of the person are used.

note.p: The personal name should preferably be entered before the family name, but processing software should not rely on this.

section.p: The name element has no attributes.

section.title: person
section.p: The element is declared as follows:

section.title: Context
section.p: draftedby, approvedby

section.title: Description
section.p: The person element contains information identifying a specific person.
The name element has no attributes.

section.title: phone
section.p: The element is declared as follows:

section.title: Description
section.p: The phone element contains a phone number. The phone number can be either an extension number or a public phone number..
The phone element has no attributes.

section.title: revdescription
section.p: The element is declared as follows:

section.title: Description
section.p: The revdescription element encloses the details of each revision of a document.
The revdescription element has no attributes.

section.title: revhistory
section.p: The element is declared as follows:

section.title: Description
section.p: The revhistory element encloses the details of revisions of a document. Revhistory can contain multiple revisions records.
The revhistory element has no attributes.

section.title: revision
section.p: The element is declared as follows:

section.title: Description
section.p: The revision element encloses the details of revisions of a document. Each record contains the information about revision number, date of revision, signature of the author responsible for the revision and comment describing reason for the revision.
The revision element has no attributes.

section.title: revnumber
section.p: The element is declared as follows:

section.title: Description
section.p: The revnumber element the revision number for a specific revision of a document.
The revnumber element has no attributes.

section.title: signature
section.p: The element is declared as follows:

section.title: Context
section.p: revision, person

section.title: Description
section.p: The signature element the signature of a person.
The signature element has no attributes.

section.title: year
section.p: The element is declared as follows:

section.title: Context
section.p: date.

section.title: Description
section.p: The year element is used to specify the year in a date element. The year must be a four-digit number.
The year element has no attributes.
